normalised: **E-commerce: Where Your Money Goes on a Digital Holiday**

unnormalised: Listen up, folks, because I'm about to drop some truth bombs about e-commerce. You think you're just browsing, maybe adding a "small" item to your cart? Think again! It's a rabbit hole, a black hole, a digital vortex sucking your hard-earned ₹ away faster than you can say "cashback offer." Last month, my own adventures began with a "necessary" purchase of 250 grams of organic Himalayan pink salt. I swear!
normalised: Listen up, folks, because I'm about to drop some truth bombs about e-commerce. You think you're just browsing, maybe adding a "small" item to your cart? Think again! It's a rabbit hole, a black hole, a digital vortex sucking your hard-earned rupees away faster than you can say "cashback offer." Last month, my own adventures began with a "necessary" purchase of two hundred and fifty grams of organic Himalayan pink salt. I swear!

unnormalised: It’s easy to get tricked. Next thing I knew, thanks to those wonderfully targeted ads, I was contemplating the merits of a 42-inch smart TV. For context, my current TV is a perfectly functional, albeit ancient, 21-inch box. But hey, "flat screen" and "limited-time deal" – what's a girl to do? The final cart value? A whopping Rs. 35,000! My brain short-circuited. I swear, 75% of my salary vanishes online.

For context, my current T-V is a perfectly functional, albeit ancient, twenty one inch box. But hey, "flat screen" and "limited-time deal" – what's a girl to do? The final cart value? A whopping rupees thirty five thousand! My brain short-circuited. I swear, seventy five percent of my salary vanishes online.

unnormalised: And let's not even talk about "free shipping." That's the siren song of e-commerce. You see something for Rs. 499, think you're being all savvy, and then BAM! – shipping charges of Rs. 99 unless you spend Rs. 999. So, naturally, you add random items you don't need to reach that magical number. I now own 3 cat sweaters (I don't have a cat!), solely because of "free shipping."

So, naturally, you add random items you don't need to reach that magical number. I now own three cat sweaters (I don't have a cat!), solely because of "free shipping."

unnormalised: Don't even get me started on the return policies. I once ordered a saree, size "free size" (which is code for "fits absolutely nobody correctly"), and it arrived looking like a crumpled tissue. Returning it involved filling out 17 forms, providing blood samples (probably), and waiting approximately 3 weeks. Final refund? Rs. 380 out of the initial Rs. 500. Victory! Or something.

unnormalised: And those "sale" prices? Oh, please. I swear, these retailers are playing games with our minds. "Original price: Rs. 5000, Now: Rs. 2500!" You think you're getting a steal, but that 'original price' never existed. It's marketing, folks! It's the illusion of savings while you're actually spending 200% more than intended.

unnormalised: So, the next time you're browsing an e-commerce site, take a deep breath, remember my cautionary tale, and ask yourself: Do I *really* need that? Or am I just falling prey to the carefully crafted algorithms designed to separate me from my money, one pink Himalayan salt purchase at a time? Your bank balance will thank you.
